title: Hepatitis B Virus Vaccine Recomb (PF) Intramuscular: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for hepatitis B virus vaccine recomb (PF) intramuscular on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is used to help prevent infection from the [hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/digestive-diseases-hepatitis-b) virus. [Hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/hepb-guide/default.htm) infection can cause serious problems failure](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-liver-failure), long-term [hepatitis](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/understanding-hepatitis-basics) B infection, [cirrhosis](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/cirrhosis-liver), and [liver cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/understanding-liver-cancer-basic-information). Preventing infection can prevent these problems. [Hepatitis B vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/hepatitis-a-and-b-vaccines) is a genetically engineered (man-made in the lab) piece of the virus. It does not contain live virus, so you cannot get hepatitis from the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). This vaccine works by helping the body produce [immunity](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/10-immune-system-busters-boosters) (through antibody production) that will prevent you from getting infection from hepatitis B virus. Hepatitis B vaccine does not protect you from other virus infections (such as [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) virus which causes AIDS; [hepatitis A](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/digestive-diseases-hepatitis-a), [genital warts](https://www.webmd.com/sexual-conditions/hpv-genital-warts/genital-warts) and other problems).The vaccine is recommended for people of all ages, especially those at an increased risk of getting the infection. Those at an increased risk include [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) personnel, lab workers who handle [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) and patient specimens, police, fire and emergency medical personnel who give [first aid](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/wound-care-10/slideshow-first-aid-essentials) treatment, hemophiliacs, [dialysis](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/kidney-dialysis) patients, people who live with or spend much time with people with long-term hepatitis B infections, people with multiple sex partners, men who have sex with men, sex workers, injection drug abusers, and people traveling to high-risk areas. [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) may not fully protect everyone who receives them. How to use Hepatitis B Virus Vacc.Rec(PF) Suspension Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before receiving the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. This vaccine is usually given by injection into a muscle ( [shoulder](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/picture-of-the-shoulder) or thigh) by a health care professional. Injection under the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) may be used if you have a bleeding disorder. Your health care professional will give you a vaccination schedule (usually a series of 2 to 4 injections), which you must follow closely for best effectiveness. If you have an illness with fever at the time a vaccination is scheduled, your health care professional may choose to delay the injection until you are better. The dosage and vaccination schedule is based on your age, medical condition, risk of [hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/digestive-diseases-hepatitis-b) exposure, and the brand of vaccine used. If you are receiving the first [hepatitis B vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/hepatitis-a-and-b-vaccines) injection at a time when your health care professional feels you may have been exposed to [hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/hepb-guide/default.htm), you will also receive an injection of [hepatitis](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/understanding-hepatitis-basics) B immune globulin (HBIG). HBIG is a dose of [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing) against the virus and will immediately help protect you from developing an infection. These antibodies only last a few months. For long-term protection, it is important to follow your vaccination schedule for the hepatitis B vaccine exactly. Side Effects Pain/soreness/redness/swelling at the injection site, fever, [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics), tiredness, [sore throat](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/understanding-sore-throat-basics), [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), loss of appetite, and [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics) may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), dizziness, [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional right away if you have any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your health care professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before you receive this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as latex rubber or yeast found in some brands), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before using this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: current illness with fever. If you are a [hemodialysis](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/hemodialysis-20667) patient, you may not respond as well to the vaccine and will need to have [hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/digestive-diseases-hepatitis-b) antibody levels checked yearly. If [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing) drop too low over time, you may be given another dose of vaccine (often called a booster shot). If you have [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment), your body may not make enough antibodies to protect you from [hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/hepb-guide/default.htm) infection. Antibody levels may be checked after the vaccine series. Older adults may not make as many antibodies to the vaccine. Talk to your health care professional for more details. During pregnancy, this vaccine should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your health care professional. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: drugs that Other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) may be given at the same time as [hepatitis B vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/hepatitis-a-and-b-vaccines), but should be given with separate syringes and at different injection sites. Overdose Not applicable. As with any [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) may not fully protect everyone who receives it. Lab and/or medical tests (such as [hepatitis B](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/digestive-diseases-hepatitis-b) antibody levels) may be done while you are using this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. Keep vaccine records for yourself and all of your children, and after your children are grown provide their records to them and their [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professionals. This will prevent unnecessary re- [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). It is important to receive each vaccination as scheduled. Be sure to ask when each dose should be received and make a note on a calendar to help you remember. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
